abstract.p: In this article, lacquer seed shell fiber-reinforced poly(lactic acid) (PLA) composites were prepared by transfer compression molding. The lacquer seed shell fiber was treated by NaOH and silane. The effect of surface treatment on the properties of the composites was studied by orthogonal experiment. It was found that the concentration of NaOH significantly affected the impact strength of the composites. The highest impact strength (6.94 kJ/m2, which is 300% higher than that of the untreated fiber-reinforced poly(lactic acid) composite) was found in the composite treated by NaOH following silane treatment. The results of thermogravimetric analysis indicated that the thermal stability of fiber-reinforced poly(lactic acid) composites were better than that of neat poly(lactic acid). Moreover, the morphology of fracture surface evaluated by scanning electron microscopy indicated that surface treatment can make better adhesion between the fiber and the matrix.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the increasing awareness of the protection of environment and the depletion of petroleum resources, biodegradable polymers, such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA), a corn-based polymer, have been the subject of many studies during the past decade.1–5 Recently, natural fiber-reinforced biocomposites have been used as automotive, construction and packaging because of their good mechanical properties and light weight. The adoption of PLA for such applications is the reason that PLA-based composites emit less CO2 compared to other petroleum-based thermoplastics.6 Also, the PLA provides good aesthetics and strength and easy processability in most equipment. However, because of the limitation of some physical properties, such as brittleness, the PLA needs modification for most practical applications.6 A way to improve the mechanical and thermal properties of the PLA is the addition of fibers or ﬁller materials.7,8

Plant fiber is a renewable resource, which is the most preferred reinforced materials for inexpensive biocomposites. Advantages of natural fiber over conventional glass fiber are low density, low cost, low energy consumption and biodegradability.9,10 The performance of natural fiber including ramie, flax, kenaf fiber, recycled newspaper fiber, hemp, silk fiber, etc. reinforced PLA composites has been investigated.5,7,9,11–16 The lacquer tree was originated in China, and there is an existing of more than 500 million plants in China. Yearly output yield of lacquer seed is more than 200 million tons, lacquer seed shell (LSS) fiber, which is a kind of seed hair and easily obtainable as wastage from lacquer seed industries, has not yet been fully utilized in the fabrication of biodegradable composites. Hence, owing to their wide variety of sources, availability and low cost effectiveness, LLS fibers can be potential reinforcement of biodegradable composites.

It is well known that the properties of composites are significantly controlled by the interface between the reinforced fibers and the matrix.7 Due to poor compatibility between hydrophilic natural fibers and hydrophobic matrix, many researchers focused on improving the interfacial adhesion by modifying the fiber surfaces via physical and chemical treatments to make them more compatible with matrix.1,17–20 The silane treatment and NaOH treatment are the most widely used modification methods of natural fiber so as to improve the adhesion between the fiber and polymer matrix. Huda et al.13 investigated the mechanical and thermal properties of kenaf-fibers–reinforced PLA composites. They found that both the silane-treated fiber (FIBSI)-reinforced composite and the alkali treated fiber (FIBNA)-reinforced composite offered superior mechanical properties compared to the untreated fiber (FIB)-reinforced composite. The alkali-treated fiber followed by silane-treated fiber (FIBNASI)-reinforced composite also significantly improved the mechanical properties. Nor Azowa Ibrahim et al.21 investigated the effect of various percentages of sodium hydroxide on the mechanical property, dynamic mechanical property and thermal properties of kenaf bast-fiber-reinforced PLA. But many researchers studied only specific NaOH (specific concentration and time) and specific silane treatment (specific concentration and time), or only did the single factor experiments of alkali treatment or silane treatment.

In the present work, LSS fiber was treated by NaOH and silane, and the multi-factor level of NaOH treatment and silane treatment was optimized with the index of impact strength by orthogonal experiment. Also, the effect of fiber treatment on the mechanical and thermal properties was evaluated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
PLA thermoplastic resin (injection molding grade) was purchased from W. W Plastic Ningbo Co., Ltd, China. LSS fibers were waste materials obtained from Hunan Handou Forestry Science and Technology Co., Ltd, China. The LSS fibers have a diameter of about 150–350 µm, and a length of 3–6 mm. The picture of lacquer seeds and LSS fibers is shown in Figure 1. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was obtained from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd, China. γ-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APS) was supplied by GBXF Silicones Co., Ltd, China. Acetic acid was obtained from Tianjin Xin Dayu Chemical Co., Ltd, China. Ethanol was supplied by Hengyang Kaixin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, China. Figure 1.
(a) Lacquer seeds and (b) lacquer seed shell fibers.

sec.title: Design of orthogonal experiment
sec.p:
Orthogonal experiment is a method of multi-factor level study, which is based on the orthogonal property from the comprehensive test to select part of the representative point test, the representative point with the homogeneous dispersion, neat comparable characteristics, and it is an efficient, economic experiment design method. The purpose of the experiments’ design was to investigate the impact strength of the composites by different fiber treatment. The four parameters were chosen as follows: A, concentration of NaOH; B, time of NaOH treatment; C, concentration of silane and D, time of silane treatment. The details of the parameters and their values are given in Table 1. Table 1.

sec.title: Fiber surface modiﬁcation
sec.p:
Raw LSS fibers contained several impurities, such as sand, mud, lacquer seed, seed grains and seed shell, which were washed out with water-flow for 5 min. Then the washed fibers were dried in an oven at 80℃ for 24 h. After that an orthogonal experiment was used to optimize the fiber pre-treatment process to improve the interfacial bonding between LSS fiber and PLA matrix, and the orthogonal experiment scheme of fiber surface treatment is shown in Table 2, which includes three methods of pre-treatments: NaOH treatment, silane treatment and NaOH treatment followed by silane treatment. sec.title: NaOH treatment
sec.p: LSS fibers were immersed in sodium hydroxide solution (2–10 wt%) for (0.5–1)h at room temperature. Then the fibers were washed with distilled water containing a few drops of acetic acid. Next, fibers were washed with distilled water until all NaOH was eliminated, subsequently neutralized to pH 7. Finally, the fibers were dried in an oven at 80℃ for 24 h. The reaction of NaOH with LSS fiber can be described as follows: LSS fiber-OH+NaOH→LSS fiber-O-Na++H2O

sec.title: Silane treatment
sec.p:
For the surface treatment of the LSS fiber, (1–5 wt%) APS (weight percentage compared to the fiber) was dissolved for hydrolysis in a mixture of water–ethanol (40:60 w/w).1,22 The pH of the solution was adjusted to 4–5 with acetic acid and stirred continuously for 0.5 h. Next, the fibers were soaked in the solution for (0.5–1.5) h. Fibers were then washed. Finally, the fibers were dried in an oven at 80℃ for 24 h. The hypothetical reaction of silanol with LSS fiber is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
The hypothetical reaction of silanol with LSS fiber.
LSS: lacquer seed shell.

sec.title: NaOH and silane treatment
sec.p: LSS fibers were firstly treated by sodium hydroxide solution as described in the NaOH treatment step, and then by APS as described in the silane-treatment step.

sec.title: Composites preparation
sec.p: To ensure that all absorbed moisture was removed and to prevent void formation, the LSS fibers and the PLA pellets were dried at 60℃ in an oven for 12 h before processing. The neat PLA was melt compounded with the LSS fiber (after treatment based on the orthogonal experiment) using a torque rheometer (Hapro RM-200A, Harbin, China) with a rotation speed of 40 r/min for 20 min at 175℃. The mass ratio of fiber and PLA is 20:80.

The specimen was prepared by transfer compression molding at the speciﬁed temperature (185℃). The materials were kept at a constant pressure of 10 MPa for 20 min to melt and then expelled the entrapped air out of the mold for 10 times. Then, they were compacted at a pressure of 10 MPa for 5 min and afterwards, the power was turned off. When the mold temperature reached 60℃, the press was removed, and cooled to the room temperature. The platens were opened and the samples were removed from the press. The results of mechanical properties were taken as the average of five test samples.

sec.title: Testing and characterization
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared spectra Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the untreated and treated fibers were detected by a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrometer, USA, using the standard KBr pellet technique in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1.

sec.title: Tensile test
sec.p:
Specimens of the composites were tested for tensile strength according to GB 13022-91 standard using a WDW-100C Machine (Shanghai Hualong Test Instruments Co., Ltd, China). The shape and dimension of the specimen are shown in Figure 3.The tensile rate was 1 mm/min. Figure 3.
Shape and measurement of specimens (mm).

sec.title: Flexural test
sec.p: The flexural properties of the composites were measured by a three-point bending method according to GB/T 9341-2008 standard using a WDW-100C Machine (Shanghai Hualong Test Instruments Co., Ltd, China). The crosshead speed was set at 5 mm/min. The dimension of flexural specimens was 80 × 10 × 4 mm3.

sec.title: Impact test
sec.p: The impact strengths of the composites were carried out by a CBD-7.5 test machine (Shanghai Hualong Test Instruments Co., Ltd, China) according to GB/T 1043.1-2008. The impact velocity was 2.9 m/s and the impact energy was 5 J. Dimensions of the samples were 62 × 10 × 4 mm3.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were performed by a NETZSCH, Germany in a platinum crucible under nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10℃/min. The temperature range was scanned from 25℃ to 600℃.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The morphologies of the impact-fractured surfaces of the composites were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Quanta 200 FEG, FEI Company) at room temperature. The samples were coated with gold using a vacuum sputter coater. The samples were viewed perpendicular to the fractured surface.

sec.title: FTIR structural analyses
sec.p:
The FTIR spectroscopy was used to confirm the chemical reactions between the disposal agents and the cellulose of the fiber. FTIR spectra of the untreated and treated LSS fibers in the region 4000–400 cm−1 are shown in Figure 4 and Table 3. The strong and broad absorption band in the range 3200–3600 cm−1 is attributed to the hydroxyl (OH) stretching,23 which is common to all the spectra. The strong peak around 2900 cm−1 in all spectra is due to the C–H stretching vibration of methyl and methylene groups in cellulose and hemicellulose.1,24 The absorption band in the region 1300–1460 cm−1 is corresponding to C–H stretching vibration of alkane methyl and methylene plane bending vibration, which indicates the presence of saturated alkane chain group in LSS fiber. The sharp peak observed in untreated LSS fiber (Figure 4–1#) at 1740 cm−1 is due to C = O stretching vibration of carboxylic acid and ester components of hemicellulose,25 whereas this peak disappears in the case of NaOH-treated fiber (Figure 4–9#), and weaker peak in shorter time NaOH-treatment fiber (Figure 4–8#). This may be attributed to the dissolution of hemicelluloses in NaOH solution.1 The bands that appear at 2920 cm−1 in the spectrum of treated fiber (Figure 4–7#, 8#, 9#) are present with reduced intensity compared to untreated fiber (Figure 4–1#), strongly revealing the reduction of fatty acid and some hemicellulose contents by the NaOH and silane treatment.24 Figure 4.

The silane-treated fibers (Figure 4–7#, 8#) reveal an absorption peak at 700 cm−1 corresponding to –Si–O–Si– symmetric stretching band.11 The reaction between hydroxyl groups on the surface of LSS fiber and the silane coupling agent can make the fiber surface more hydrophobic thereby increasing the wetting of PLA matrix, which may enhance interfacial adhesion. The peaks at 881 cm−1 and 887 cm−1 may be due to the Si-cellulose bond, which indicates the reaction between LSS fiber and silane.26

sec.p:

It can be seen from Table 5 that the optimal combination for impact strength is A3B2C2D3, and the concentration of NaOH is the main factor affecting the impact strength. This may contribute to the NaOH treatment which can remove residual lignin, wax and oils covering on the external surface of the fiber cell wall, thereby producing a rough surface topography, increasing the wetting between the fiber and the matrix.13,27 Treatment with NaOH leads to a decrease in the spiral angle and an increase in molecular orientation.28 But the time of NaOH treatment, concentration of silane and time of silane treatment have less effect on the impact strength compared to the concentration of NaOH. The order of various factors on the impact strength is concentration of NaOH > time of NaOH treatment> time of silane treatment> concentration of silane. As can be seen from Table 6, the concentration of NaOH has significant impact on impact strength.

sec.title: Effect of NaOH treatment on the mechanical properties of the composites
sec.p: The best combination for impact strength of composites obtained from the orthogonal test is A3B2C2D3, and the key factor to affect the impact strength of composites is the concentration of NaOH. In order to study the effect of the NaOH concentration on the mechanical properties of the composites, the fibers were firstly treated by different NaOH concentration (5%, 10%, 15%) for 0.5 h, then treated by 3% silane solution for 1 h.

The effects of different NaOH concentration on flexural properties and tensile properties are shown in Figure 5(a) and (b) and in Figure 6(a) and (b), respectively. It is clear that the tensile properties behave the similar trend as the flexural properties. All NaOH-treated followed by silane-treated fibers composites show the same tendency of significantly increase in the flexural and tensile modulus compared to the only silane-treated composite. The 5% NaOH-treated followed by silane-treated fiber composite achieves the maximum flexural modulus and tensile modulus, which improved by 11% and 48% as compared to the non-NaOH-treated fiber composite, respectively. With further increase in the NaOH concentration, the flexural modulus increased slightly as compared to the non-NaOH-treated fiber composites. Enhancement of tensile modulus and flexural modulus may be due to the increase in fiber stiffness by the NaOH treatment. According to Huda et al.,13 the chemical treatments have a lasting effect on the mechanical behavior of natural ﬁbers, especially on fiber stiffness.

As can be seen from Figure 5(b) and 6(b), when treated by 5% alkali, the flexural strength and tensile strength are both decreased. This may be due to the low efficiency in removing the impurities on the fiber surfaces at low concentrations of NaOH treatment, thus resulting in poor adhesion between the fiber and the matrix.29 In the case of 10% NaOH-treated fiber composite, there is a slight increase in the flexural strength and tensile strength. However, for the 15% NaOH-treated fiber composite, both the flexural strength and tensile strength decreased with greater fibrillation owing to the relatively larger fiber ends available for crack initiation. This could lower the effective stress transfer at the interface.30

The effects of different concentration of the NaOH on impact properties are shown in Figure 7. The impact properties of the composites with NaOH treatment followed by silane are superior than that of the silane treatment composite. The impact strength has been improved by the increase in the NaOH concentration. The maximum value of it is observed at the concentration of 10% (7.6 kJ/m2, which is 173% higher than the non-NaOH-treated composite). This may be due to the increased surface roughness, which provides additional sites for mechanical interlocking, thereby giving rise to better fiber/matrix adhesion.1 However, the trend is decreased when the concentration of NaOH is increased to 15%, this may due to high concentration leading a damage to the fibers interlaminar bonding.31

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p:
The thermal stability of pure PLA and LSS fiber/PLA composites was investigated with thermal analysis. Thermogravimetric (TG) curves as a function of temperature of pure PLA and different surface-treatment composites are shown in Figure 8. Table 7 shows the degradation temperature values (Td) calculated as the maximum of degradation rate, and the temperature of 95%, 50% and 5% residual weight. It is observed from Figure 8 that the thermal stability of fiber-reinforced PLA composites is better than the neat PLA. The degradation temperature values of neat PLA, composites S1, S7, S8 and S9 is 369℃, 386℃, 391℃, 390℃ and 381℃, respectively. Higher thermal stability of composites as compared to neat PLA may be attributed to the higher thermal stability of the LSS fiber. But, the degradation temperature of composites commences at relatively lower temperature than that of neat PLA. TG curve of neat PLA shows a single-step thermal degradation from 280℃ to 440℃. The silane treated composite S7 has the best thermal stability of the composites. Improved thermal stability may be due to removal of some easily hydrolyzed substances, which decompose at temperatures lower than the main constituents (cellulose and lignin).1 However, the char yields of LSS-reinforced composites are all larger than that of neat PLA. The results indicate that the addition of LSS fiber to PLA would effectively raise the char yields of the samples.10 The char yield is directly related to the potency of flame retardation for polymers. Increasing char formation can limit the production of combustible gases, decrease the exothermicity of the pyrolysis reaction, and inhibit the thermal conductivity of the burning materials.32 Table 7.

sec.title: Fractured surface morphologies of the composites
sec.p:
The fracture surface morphology of untreated and treated composites was analyzed by SEM as shown in Figures 9 to 12, where matrix is highlighted with arrows, holes are remarked by 1, fibers-fractured are remarked by 2 and fibers pulled-out are remarked by 3. Figure 9 shows many big caverns which were left by the pulled-out fibers. The fibers were pulled out with relatively clean surface and without matrix on surface, but with some impurities such as wax on the fiber surface (see Figure 9(b)), which indicated a low adhesion between the fiber and the matrix. Poor adhesion is a result of the presence of wax, pectin and other impurities. SEM micrographs of the treated composites in Figures 10 to 12 obviously indicate that surface treatment facilitates good adhesion between LSS fiber and PLA matrix. Fewer voids can be seen in Figure 10 than the morphology of the untreated composite, and the LSS fiber adherences to the PLA. It was deduced that the silane had been trapped by the PLA matrix. Many fractured fibers can be seen in Figure 11(a). In Figure 11(b), the pulled-out fiber has been covered with a thick layer by the matrix linking the fiber surface to the matrix, and thus better stress transfer could be expected. It implies that the treatment of NaOH followed by silane played an important role as compatibilizer between the LSS fiber and the PLA matrix. Figure 12 shows a rather smooth morphology which is different from Figures 9 to 11. Smaller voids can be seen in the figure as compared to Figure 9. The fiber has been coated by a layer of matrix and closely adhered to the matrix. It can be explained that NaOH treatment has dissolved pectin, waxy and other impurities, thus forming a smaller diameter of fiber and a roughness surface, enhancing a better compatibility between the fiber and the matrix. The results indicate that the treatment of fibers play an important role in the adhesion between fiber and PLA matrix and explain why the impact strength of treated fiber-reinforced composites is better than the untreated composite. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, mechanical and thermal properties of LSS fiber-reinforced PLA have been studied as a function of fiber surface treatments. FTIR spectroscopic studies revealed the chemical reaction after the fiber treatment. The concentration of NaOH has a significant effect on the impact strength. Tensile strength and flexural strength of the composites firstly decreased, then increased and then decreased with the increase in the concentration of NaOH. Along with the increasing concentration of NaOH, the impact strength increased initially, and then decreased. The maximum improvement in tensile strength, flexural strength and impact strength was observed in the 10% NaOH treatment followed by silane treatment composites. TGA revealed that the thermal stability of fiber-reinforced PLA composites is better than the neat PLA. The SEM photographs of fracture surfaces of composites clearly indicated the extent of fiber–matrix interface adhesion.
